results.title: Al fresco
results.creator_credit: Mario Andreacchio, Barbara Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In Adelaide’s Al Fresco Gelataria the young and the single meet friends, watch the passing scene of Rundle St. or strike up new relationships. Part of Adelaide’s thriving cafe society, the patrons of Al Fresco talk about their reasons for coming there, their attitude to peer groups and peer group pressure and how they relate to each other.

results.title: Independent company
results.creator_credit: Colin South, John Tatoulis and Media World
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Warriors”.
The story of Sparrow Force, the Australian 2/2 Independent Company, a specially trained troop of Australian soldiers sent to join Dutch forces in Timor in 1941, to defend Northern Australia against the Japanese advance. The program uses interviews with surviving Company members, as well as their Japanese opponents, mixed with re-enactments of their experiences. The interviews reveal that without the selfless assistance of the Timorese, the Australian troops would not have survived. The program also features footage shot by Academy Award winning Australian news cameraman, Damien Parer, who was killed in action in New Guinea.

results.title: Grant Mudford. Max Pam
results.creator_credit: Jeff Atkinson, Roger Young, Brian Beaton, Kevin Ballantine and Izon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Visual instincts : Australian contemporary photographers”.
Two thirty minute programs: 1. “Grant Mudford” Born in Australia in 1944, photographer, Grant Mudford, now lives and works in California. He prefers anonymous architectural subject matter photographed in a manner that transforms it. 2. “Max Pam” Born in Melbourne, Max Pam left at age 19 for Katmandu. He returned to Australia in 1984 having established an international reputation as a photographer of Asia. Photography, for Pam, has the capacity to capture certain moments which elude the writer, the filmmaker or the painter.

results.title: W. H. Auden: poet and critic
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker and Dynamic Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Writers of today”.
British poet, W. H. Auden, and New York Herald Tribune drama critic Walter Kerr, smoke their way through this entertaining discussion on the role of the poet and poetry in the modern world. The program is a reissue of an interview originally recorded in the ‘50s for the Educational Television & Radio Center. In it, Auden holds forth on the essentials for a good poet, poetry as magic or play, and the estrangement of the poet in a technological society. A highlight is Auden’s moving recitation of his own poem on poetry - “The truest poetry is the most feigning”.

results.title: Youth and credit (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Geoff Scott presents a dramatised story of a young man who encounters a series of escalating problems with credit, relating to the purchase of a car. The film is then discussed with an invited audience of teenagers and ‘experts’ with the aim of introducing safe ways of handling credit. The video is accompanied by Teacher’s notes. Pt. 1. The forum. Pt. 2. Eddy: a trigger film.

results.title: Twelve angry men = 12 angry men
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Henry Fonda, Reginald Rose and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: A tense and brilliantly directed drama focusing on twelve men in a jury who are considering a verdict on a case of a young Puerto Rican youth charged with murder. Henry Fonda plays the impassioned man of reason, not convinced of the guilt of the accused and battling against his eleven co-jurors who all want to convict the teenager and leave the hot and sweaty jury room. The film is famous for its condemnation of capital punishment. Also stars Lee J. Cobb, Jack Warden and Jack Klugman.

results.title: Japanese for Beginners. Part 3: Episodes 21-30
results.brief_description: The third part of a forty episode video program designed to introduce a beginner to the necessary vocabulary and phrases needed for “daily survival” in Japan. The programs introduce us to David, a young English businessman, as he learns his way around Japanese society. Exuberant techno-graphics are used as a visual aid in introducing David, and the viewer, to the language. The videos offer information on transport, shopping, finding a hotel, as well as important advice on working and living in Japan.

results.title: The Money or the gun = The International year of the patronising bastard (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Martin Coombes, Mark Fitzgerald and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A special episode of “The money or the gun” which looks at the community’s attitudes to the disabled. Andrew Denton interviews members of the public and of the disabled community in an attempt to promote a less patronising approach to the physically handicapped. Also known as “The International Year of the Patronising Bastard”. This program has won international awards.

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 7 & 8
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel Four, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: Sipping stars recounts the history of champagne, from its invention by Dom Perignon during the reign of Louis XIV, the addition of the bubbles by the British during the reign of Charles II and the introduction of mass production methods by La Veuve Clicquot which led to its international success. “Wine and war” shows how the sweet fortified wines, particularly Madeira and Port were embraced by the British and Americans when French and German wines became unobtainable during the Napoleonic wars.

results.title: Buongiorno Italia! [kit]
results.creator_credit: Alan Wilding, Maddalena Fagandini and BBC
results.brief_description: A kit for the Italian for beginners’ course, “Buongiorno Italia!”, containing three 60 minute audio cassettes for pronunciation practice, a copy of “Teachers’ Notes” and a copy of the student text for the course. See also the double video sets, “Buongiorno Italia!” programs 1-10 and 11-20.
